ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My knowledge was nothing more than basic. This course dramatically improved my knowledge and my way of thinking about the topic. It was of primary importance for improving my background in prevision of my PhD.

I learned a great deal about cell types and single-cell sequencing. It was great to read the recent literature on cell type identity and evolution. Delving into very recent advances in single-cell sequencing was also very helpful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think there is nothing to add in terms of quality and requests. Maybe I would add a couple of hours of practice in the lab to show even the practical part regarding this topic.

This course does a great job tapping into the current literature on important topics in cell type evolution and single-cell sequencing. It's really helpful to learn about the current state of the literature. In some cases, it would have been good to have more background literature on certain topics, such as sequencing technology. More group discussion of papers would be great, though that's partly contingent on the students in the class. The student presentations are a good way to engage the class and start a discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The course revealed to be essential for what I needed.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student interested in cell type evolution and single-cell sequencing. Given the highly specific nature of the course, I would only recommend it to students with similar interests.
